thread.title: Twitter sued for scanning private messages
thread.title_full: Twitter sued for scanning private messages

author: admin
title: Twitter sued for scanning private messages
text:
Twitter Sued For Eavesdropping On Direct Messages ° 15th Sep 2015 , A class action lawsuit alleges Twitter eavesdrops on its users’ private messages. In the lawsuit filed Monday by Wilford Raney and others in federal court in San Francisco, claims that the company systematically intercepts, reads, and alters the private ... 
Twitter Is Being Sued for Scanning Direct Messages ° 15th Sep 2015 , The lawsuit says the company has been “systematically intercepting, reading, and altering” direct messages, most likely a reference to Twitter’s longstanding practice of automatically shortening and redirecting any in-message links. While the ... 
Twitter accused of eavesdropping on direct messages in new lawsuit ° 15th Sep 2015 , Sending direct messages are a way for Twitter users to communicate out of the public eye, but a new lawsuit alleges those communications are not really so private. A class action ... deal with accusations of message scanning. 
Yes, Twitter Scans Your Private Messages, But Did The Company Properly Disclose It? ° 15th Sep 2015 , Private messaging scanning has been happening for awhile at ... distinguish between public or private messages in its altering. The lawsuit points to how Twitter defines its Direct Messages as private in several other places, however. 
Twitter sued for scanning private messages ° 15th Sep 2015 , Twitter's San Francisco headquarters (Photo: Justin Sullivan, Getty Images) SAN FRANCISCO — A lawsuit filed this week in San Francisco federal court alleges Twitter is "surreptitiously eavesdropping" on people who send private messages on the social ... 
Twitter Hit With Class Action Lawsuit for Eavesdropping on Direct Messages ° 15th Sep 2015 , ... surreptitiously eavesdrops on its users’ private Direct Message communications. As soon as a user sends a Direct Message, Twitter intercepts, reads, and, at times, even alters the message." The lawsuit uses a link to The New York Times as an example.
